abstracts.cdata!:
The Railway Restructuring Project for
            Poland had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Following are some of the lessons learned: Under the
            Project, a total of 37,000 employees, or over 20 percent of
            Polish State Railways (PKP) labor force was reduced between
            August 2000 and January 2003 rapidly but smoothly with no
            evidence of labor tension. Implementation of the overall
            Program, in particular the legal and organizational
            restructuring to split a monolithic Railways into a number
            of subsidiaries and the parent company, was highly
            satisfactory. A protracted period of project preparation
            time can be worthwhile when: (1) it enables the negotiations
            necessary to build political will for a difficult social
            change, (2) it keeps dialogue open while events bring more
            clarity and pressure on the decision makers. Even
            substantial restructuring successes can fail to achieve
            financial goals when the overall business environment
            evolves negatively. Neither PKP nor Agency for Retraining
            and Reemployment ( KAAZ) really saw World Bank social
            safeguards as part of their core activity and to undertake
            the post-layoff social monitoring. The European Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development loan did not include a social
            monitoring component and started one year ahead of the Bank
            loan. An explicit project performance indicator should have
            been included related to the monitoring and evaluation of
            the labor redundancy activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Employment restructuring and occupational
            activation of employees of Polskie Koleje Panstwowe (Polish
            State Railways), in the years 2000 - 2002

abstracts.cdata!:
Reforms of the Polish State Railways
            state owned enterprise (PKP), the national carrier in Polish
            railway sector, were implemented over a period of
            1990-2002with general view to restructure the entity and
            make it more efficient in delivering the function of a
            public railway transport carrier passengers and goods in
            line with the European Union principles of operations. The
            reform followed general trend of the beginning of nineties,
            when Poland first aspired to become a member state. The
            scope of PKP transformations of therefore driven in general
            by the acquis communautaire in the field of common transport
            policy for railways and in particular in orientation, scopes
            and methods adopted by the EU member states undertaking
            similar restructuring schemes and other countries, which
            like the Poland aspired to become a member state.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Railway Restructuring Project aims
            to restructure Polish State Railways' (PKP) to increase
            efficiency, improve finances, and privatize selected
            activities within a sound regulatory framework. The project
            consists of three components. The first component will
            support temporary income support measures, which will be
            offered as part of the comprehensive restructuring,
            commercialization, and partial privatization of PKP. These
            measures are made up of general social benefits from
            existing general income support programs, and special
            severance packages anticipated for PKP layoffs. The second
            component will support the Labor Redeployment Programs,
            which are made up of re-qualification training as well as
            professional and social advice and other forms of
            professional guidance. These include general labor
            redeployment programs, and special labor redeployment
            programs anticipated for PKP layoffs. The third component
            will support technical assistance to advise the Ministry of
            Transport and the main railway enterprises on the
            organizational, legal, regulatory, financial, and social
            aspects of the program.
